abstract: The departure of Home Depot’s chief was a victory for shareholders hoping to force corporate directors to be more accountable for executive pay.
snippet: The departure of Home Depot’s chief was a victory for shareholders hoping to force corporate directors to be more accountable for executive pay.
lead_paragraph: Arrogance has never been attractive in a leader. Now, in corporate chief executives anyhow, it may be a career ender.

headline.main: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs
headline.print_headline: A Warning Shot by Investors to Boards and Chiefs

abstract: The board decided that Robert L. Nardelli should go — with a $210 million exit package.
snippet: The board decided that Robert L. Nardelli should go — with a $210 million exit package.
lead_paragraph: In May, in a nearly empty basement ballroom at the Hotel du Pont in Wilmington, Del., Robert L. Nardelli, the chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, stood between huge timers, intended to limit questions from the handful of shareholders present. After dismissing questions about his compensation or the independence of the board, Mr. Nardelli abruptly ended the meeting after only 30 minutes.

headline.main: Home Depot Ousts Highly Paid Chief
headline.print_headline: Home Depot Board Ousts Chief, Saying Goodbye With Big Check

byline.original: By Julie Creswell and Michael Barbaro

abstract: Robert L. Nardelli’s departure illustrates that even when investor voices are heard on executive pay, shareholders often wind up holding the bag.
snippet: Robert L. Nardelli’s departure illustrates that even when investor voices are heard on executive pay, shareholders often wind up holding the bag.
lead_paragraph: Robert L. Nardelli’s rich compensation and poor performance at Home Depot have long been cited by shareholder activists as a prime example of what they view as excessive executive pay. Some union members dressed up in giant chicken outfits to protest the board’s reluctance to clip Mr. Nardelli’s wings.

headline.main: An Ousted Chief’s Going-Away Pay Is Seen by Many as Typically Excessive
headline.print_headline: An Ousted Chief’s Going-Away Pay Is Seen by Many as Typically Excessive

abstract: General Electric has long been seen as a training ground for future C.E.O.’s. The ouster of Robert L. Nardelli, a G.E. alumnus, may change that perception.
snippet: General Electric has long been seen as a training ground for future C.E.O.’s. The ouster of Robert L. Nardelli, a G.E. alumnus, may change that perception.
lead_paragraph: When boards of directors go shopping for a new chief executive, their first stop is often General Electric.

headline.main: G.E. Magic Can Fade, After G.E.
headline.print_headline: G.E. Magic Can Fade, After G.E.

abstract: As shareholders, industry watchers and lawmakers continued to express outrage over the $210 million golden farewell that Home Depot awarded its ousted chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, The New York Times takes a look at where it all began: General Electric, which has become a kind of high-end boutique where company directors go when they are looking for the cream of the crop in chief executives.
lead_paragraph: As shareholders, industry watchers and lawmakers continued to express outrage over the $210 million golden farewell that Home Depot awarded its ousted chief executive, Robert L. Nardelli, The New York Times takes a look at where it all began: General Electric, which has become a kind of high-end boutique where company directors go when they are looking for the cream of the crop in chief executives.

headline.main: Home Depot Moves Put G.E., Martin Lipton in Spotlight

abstract: Bob Nardelli could not see the value of good pay — at least for others.
snippet: Bob Nardelli could not see the value of good pay — at least for others.
lead_paragraph: There is a wonderful irony to the departure of Bob Nardelli from Home Depot.
